content: The List.splitInTwo function signature has some kind of dependent-type-looking constraint marked with // in its documentation: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Init/Data/List/Sort/Basic.html#List.splitInTwo . I can't find where this syntax is documented, or how I'd turn the result of this function into an ordinary List Nat.
Oh, dear, splitInTwo should surely be private, that is an implementation detail of mergeSort. (Done: lean#6380.)

but to answer your question, the expression {x : A // p x} is syntax for docs#Subtype, which as you might guess represents an element of A such that p x holds. It's a separate type from the base type A - it's a structure, so you can get the underlying value by using .1 or docs#Subtype.val, and you can create elements of the subtype using the anonymous constructor notation ⟨x, h⟩ where h is a proof of p x.

so if you wanted to convert a p : { l : List α // l.length = (n + 1) / 2 } into a List α you just write p.1. And in fact there is a coercion from one to the other, so in many situations just p alone will also work
